journal-title-group.journal-title: European Journal of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine

title-group.article-title: Explore the Overall Benefit Index and its correlation with item difficulty among dysphagia-related syndromes in the ICF framework

contrib-group.aff: 1Hunan Provincial People’s Hospital, The First Affiliated Hospital of Hunan Normal University, Changsha, China; 2Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, Sir Run Run Hospital, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, China; 3School of Medicine, Center of Rehabilitation Therapy, The First Rehabilitation Hospital of Shanghai, Tongji University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Chun Feng, School of Medicine, Center of Rehabilitation Therapy, The First Rehabilitation Hospital of Shanghai, Tongji University, Shanghai, China. E-mail: 23310107@tongji.edu.cn

fn.p: Authors’ contributions: Feng Lin and Chun Feng have given substantial contributions to the study conception; Ya-Cen Wu and Yan-Qun Luo contributed to the data collection, and to the study as first authors; Feng Lin contributed to the data analysis and to the provision of figures; Chun Feng, Ya-Cen Wu, and Yan-Qun Luo contributed to the manuscript draft, all authors revised it critically. All authors read and approved the final version of the manuscript.

license.license-p: This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives (CC BY-NC-ND) 4.0 License.

sec.title: BACKGROUND
sec.p: Individuals with dysphagia typically experience multiple co-occurring symptoms, whose interrelationships can vary in strength. The significance and impact of each symptom within dysphagia also differ. However, the intricate web of connections among these symptoms remains poorly understood, making it challenging to assess the importance of individual symptoms from a relational perspective.

sec.title: AIM
sec.p: The aim of this study was to: 1) construct a correlation map that identifies the risk associations within dysphagia-related syndromes; and 2) rank syndromes according to the Overall Benefit Index (OBI) of a specific functional intervention, which varies in their impact on the overall functional status.

sec.title: DESIGN
sec.p: This study has a cross-sectional design.

sec.title: SETTING
sec.p: The setting of this study was a tertiary hospital in Hunan Province, China.

sec.title: POPULATION
sec.p: Population considered in this study included patients with non-esophageal dysphagia.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Adopting convenience sampling, we recruited 150 patients with dysphagia to assess their health-related quality of life through the dysphagia-specific International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) Scale. A network structure of 50 second-level or third-level ICF categories was investigated by the Ising model. The Bayesian model was applied to determine the probability of the existence of the connection among ICF functional categories.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: The resulting network consisted of 50 nodes and 64 connections. 48 functional categories demonstrated a significant OBI, with “d9102 Ceremonies” (OBI=1.00) achieving the highest OBI. “d9204 Hobbies” (OBI=0.862), and “d9205 Socializing” (OBI=0.847) were another top two categories with the 2nd and 3rd highest OBI. There was a significant correlation between network parameters, OBI, and item difficulty. Specifically, item difficulty showed a positive correlation with OBI (P<0.001, rPearson=0.712), indicating that more challenging items tend to correspond with higher OBIs.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The Ising model is a powerful tool that can assist rehabilitation clinicians in better understanding the complex functional network and guide specific rehabilitation interventions for patients with dysphagia.

sec.title: CLINICAL REHABILITATION IMPACT
sec.p: Cooperating the item difficulties from the Item Response Theory (IRT) into the OBI from the Ising model could guide individualized clinical decisions based on item difficulties and importance.

kwd-group.title: Key words:
kwd-group.kwd: International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health

award-group.funding-source: National Natural Science Foundation of China
Shanghai Rising-Star Program and Shanghai Sailing Program
Natural Science Foundation of Hunan Province, China
Clinical Medical Technology Innovation Guidance Project of Hunan Provincial Science and Technology Department, China
Hunan Provincial People’s Hospital National Natural Science Foundation of China Cultivation Project
Natural Science Foundation of Changsha, China

body.p: Ingestion is fundamental to sustaining life and also serves as a social ritual that strengthens bonds among friends and family. Leopold et al.1 proposed a comprehensive research framework to understand the ingestion process, delineating five phases: the preoral (anticipatory) phase, preparatory phase, lingual phase, pharyngeal phase, and esophageal phase. Dysphagia, characterized by disruptions in one or more of these stages, can lead to a spectrum of physical and psychological health challenges,2 affecting both the individual’s well-being and their enjoyment of this vital social activity.3, 4

Dysphagia often triggers a cascade of interrelated complications. For instance, choking (pulmonary) can lead to psychological distress such as fear of choking (psychology), promoting patients to avoid eating and drinking. This avoidance increases the risk of malnutrition (nutritional)5 and delirium (dehydration),6 which in turn not only compromises patients’ overall health but also raises the risk of developing pneumonia (pulmonary). This interplay suggests a potentially vicious cycle of worsening health outcomes for individuals with dysphagia.

Effective management of dysphagia necessitates a multidisciplinary approach, engaging professionals such as physicians, speech-language pathologists, nurses, gastroenterologists, otolaryngologists, nutritionists, and dietitians to address the various aspects of assessment, treatment, and long-term care.3 The International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) facilitates communication among these professionals by providing a common language and biopsychosocial framework, allowing for understanding health and functioning in a cohesive and standardized approach.7

In rehabilitation medicine, functional assessments are crucial to inform rehabilitation goal setting and treatment strategies.8 However, assessing dysphagia with nearly 1500 ICF items is impractical. To address this challenge, the Item Response Theory (IRT) has proven to be a valuable tool for extracting highly discriminative items to form reliable and valid assessment scales.9, 10 Our previous research applies the IRT to develop a parametric measurement model based on the ICF. The ICF framework lays the theoretical foundation for item selection and categorization, while IRT offers the statistical methods to refine these assessment tools.

This parametric item response model (IRM) can generate the Wright map or item-person map, enabling the estimation and comparison of item difficulties (i.e., the probability of specific dysphagia-related symptoms being improved) and the functional abilities of individuals with dysphagia on a unified logit scale.11 This framework enhances measurement precision and supports personalized treatment planning. Clinicians can use these insights to collaboratively set realistic, evidence-based treatment goals with patients, aligning therapeutic strategies with symptom severity and individual swallowing performance.11-16

To prioritize the intervention sequence for dysfunctional tasks, a straightforward approach is to rank items by relative difficulty. However, when managing multiple dysfunctions, clinical practice extends beyond simple progression from easier to harder tasks. The goal of a tailored therapeutic intervention transcends merely alleviating discrete symptoms; it seeks to initiate a cascade effect that resolves related symptoms and improves the patient’s overall health-related function by targeting key symptoms or modifying environmental factors. A deeper analysis of interactions among functional impairments is essential to optimize the therapeutic approach. This approach is in line with Tesio et al.17 who advocate that physical and rehabilitation medicine should embrace “relational” and “functional” perspectives, underscoring the importance of an analytical and experimental approach to delve into the intricacies of “function.”

Additionally, it is necessary to concurrently monitor both the rehabilitation process and its outcomes. When different rehabilitation strategies yield similar outcomes, identifying the symptoms that have the greatest influence within the functional network can provide substantial clinical value. This strategy might enhance rehabilitation efficacy and illuminate the most impactful treatment routes, which aligns with concepts of value-based health care to balance improvement in a patient’s health outcomes for the cost of achieving that improvement.18

Graph modeling is a statistical method used to discern and visualize conditional dependencies among variables,19, 20 which offers opportunities to understand complex relationships of dysphagia-related symptoms to clarify the interactions among impairments and the factors driving their persistence. The graphical model (GM) considers variables as nodes, with conditional associations between variables forming the connections (also known as “edges”) between nodes, weighted by partial correlation coefficients. Recently, GMs have been increasingly applied to interpret complex multimorbidity patterns21 and explore genetic and protein structures.20 By mapping associations among functional items, GMs contribute to visualizing complex associations between domains of functioning and facilitating a better understanding of how “functional categories” interact. Additionally, GMs offer an opportunity to identify potential targets for rehabilitation interventions at both the personal and environmental levels22 and reveal pathways for targeted rehabilitation interventions.22 For instance, decreasing the environmental sounds (node A) improves cognitive attention (node B), which enhances swallowing performance (node C).

In recent years, Ising models have been employed to investigate the effects of interventions via simulated, symptom-specific perturbations in psychopathology.23-26 The Ising model was originally proposed to study phase transitions and magnetic interactions in physical systems, which have also made interdisciplinary contributions.27 In the framework of GMs, the Ising model illustrates a dramatic qualitative change in the state of a system due to small measurable changes in node states that are influenced by the interactions between nodes. The example is that small improvements in “intrusive thoughts” may push the system past a critical threshold, leading to improvement in post-traumatic stress disorder symptom.23

Integrating GMs with ICF-based data has shown the potential to generate clinical insights and refine our understanding of human functioning.7 For example, Kalisch et al.28 construct GMs to analyze the relationship of ICF codes, which provide a broader perspective on human functioning by visualizing dependencies, reducing dimensionality, and estimating intervention impacts. Similarly, Dong et al.29 apply GMs to evaluate poststroke dysphagia, identifying 21 critical ICF codes from Threat’s 60-Item Scale,30 and highlighting “b140 Attention functions” and “b5101 Biting” as prominent codes in the network and considered critical therapeutic targets.

GM has rarely been combined with the IRM, leading to a gap in the simultaneous analysis of the difficulty parameters from IRT with network parameters from GMs. This disparity raises unresolved questions regarding the correlation between items identified as challenging and their role as pivotal nodes within the network, as well as the potential for interventions targeting these high-difficulty or key items to significantly improve a patient’s overall functional performance. To address these questions, further investigation is crucial to uncover the interplay between the significance and difficulty of functional items.

In this study, we developed the GM to examine the topology of the IRT-validated dysphagia ICF items11 and to rank key interventional nodes regarding their impact on overall functional performance. We hypothesized that applying the Ising model alongside Bayesian learning would enhance the interpretive power of IRT-derived outcome measures and reveal specific interventions with the most substantial benefits for health. This approach has the potential to inform more personalized and effective treatment strategies for dysphagia management.

sec.title: Study design and database
sec.p: This cross-sectional study received approval from the Ethics Committee of the local hospital of Shanghai (IRB# YK-2023-01-001) before data collection. The study was conducted in adherence to the principles outlined in the Helsinki Declaration.

A convenience sampling methodology was utilized for a cross-sectional functional evaluation of individuals with non-esophageal dysphagia in a tertiary hospital.11 Tertiary hospitals as the top tier in China’s three-tiered postacute care rehabilitation system, offer intensive inpatient rehabilitation and comprehensive medical support for patients who have recently completed the acute phase of treatment. The recruitment period spanned from June 1 to December 30, 2023. Verbal or written informed consent was obtained from all participants before their inclusion in the study.

The inclusion criteria have been mentioned in the previous publication11 including: 1) age ≥18 years; and patients diagnosed with dysphagia with aspiration or food residue using the gold standard of either videofluoroscopic swallow studies (VFSS) or fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FESS). The exclusion criteria were patients diagnosed with esophageal dysphagia.

The methodology of the data collection process has been outlined in our previous works.12-14, 31 Participants with non-esophageal dysphagia were evaluated by a comprehensive assessment battery that included a dysphagia-specific ICF Scale, as well as other dysphagia-related evaluation tools. Those evaluation scales included the Swallowing-Quality of Life (SWAL-QoL) Questionnaire, Mini-Nutritional Assessment Short-Form (MNA-SF), Repetitive Saliva Swallowing Test (RSST), Modified Water Swallowing Test (MWST), Functional Oral Intake Scale (FOIS), and Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE). Interviews were conducted by healthcare professionals (YC.W and YQ.L), who underwent specialized training in the application and principles of the ICF. The final determination of each patient’s functional status was achieved through a combination of personal interviews, review of medical records, clinical examinations, and technical investigations. Our study adopted a real-world performance perspective rather than capacity measurements in a standardized environment. This approach is consistent with the ICF biopsychosocial model, which emphasizes that the “function” represents a dynamic interplay between individuals and their environmental context.17

The severity of dysfunction within each ICF category was quantified by the ICF Qualifier Scale, which ranges from 0 to 4, as follows: “no impairment (0-4%),” “mild impairment (5-24%),” “moderate impairment (25-49%),” “severe impairment (50-95%),” and “complete impairment (96-100%).” As for evaluating environmental factors, it can be either a facilitating effect (+1, +2, +3, +4) or a hindering impact (1, 2, 3, 4) on the physical and social environment as well as the attitudinal system. A score of 0 is indicative of neither a facilitator nor a barrier. Furthermore, qualifiers 8 and 9 denote “not specified” (when the available information was insufficient to quantify the severity of the impairment) and “not applicable” (when the category was inapplicable to the patient’s condition), respectively.

This article shared the same dataset as a previously published study11 but employed different binarization strategies and modeling approaches. While the earlier study focused on comparing item difficulties with person abilities based on IRM, this current work aimed to visualize interrelationships among functional items and identify the Overall Benefit Index (OBI) for each item via item-specific functional intervention based on GM. Therefore, this study outlined feasible intervention pathways and quantified the effect of specific interventions on the overall ICF Functional Scale. Figure 1 provides a visual representation of the research trajectory, involving the development of the dysphagia ICF item bank and modeling processes of IRM and GM.

caption.p: —The flow chart of development of dysphagia ICF bank and modeling pathways of Item response model and graphical model. The grey highlighted section illustrates the graphical modeling process, including the Ising model with Bayesian structure learning, the construction of the risk-related relationship network, and the calculation of the OBI. OBI: Overall Benefit Index; ICF: International Classification of Functioning; Disability and Health; MHM: monotone homogeneity model; npIRM: non-parametric item response model; pIRM: parametric item response model; DIF: differential item functioning; DTF: differential test functioning.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The analytical procedures were carried out using R statistical software (Version 4.4.1; R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria).32 Multivariate correlation analysis and heatmap visualization were performed with the bruceR package (version 2024.6).33 The BDgraph package was used for Bayesian structure learning in GMs, enabling the exploration of the graph space through the birth-death Markov Chain Monte Carlo (BDMCMC) algorithm, by dynamically adding or removing links within the network.34 Network parameter calculations and visualization were performed using the igraph package.35 To calculate the OBI and identify the most efficient, dysfunction-specific intervention target in the dysphagia-related symptom networks, we applied the NodeIdentifyR Algorithm (NIRA).23

sec.title: Data shaping
sec.p: 50 IRT-validated dysphagia-related ICF items were used to construct the Ising model integrated with Bayesian structure learning. In brief, each ICF item of the dysphagia-related scale (i.e., functional items and environmental factors) was represented as a node, whereas associations between nodes were represented as “edges.” The ICF functioning rating scores, initially on a five-point scale (0-1-2-3-4), were converted to a dichotomous scale (0-1-1-1-1). The environmental factors rating scores, initially on a nine-point scale (+4, +3, +2, +1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4), were converted to a dichotomous scale (0-0-0-0-0-1-1-1-1). This dichotomization approach assigned a score of 0 to those categorized as “unimpaired function/facilitator” and a score of 1 to functional categories identified as “impaired/limited function/hinder.” Qualifiers 8 and 9 were considered as missing data.

sec.title: Graph modeling
sec.p: Graph modeling was divided into three steps as follows:

list-item.p: calculation of the posterior probability of the connection – a Bayesian GM for binary data, using a “dgm-binary” approach based on marginal pseudo-likelihood. The Birth-Death Markov Chain Monte Carlo (bdmcmc) algorithm was employed to estimate the posterior probability of connections within the network, with prior probabilities set to 0.2. Running for 5000 iterations (2500 burn-in), the algorithm initiated from an empty network and iteratively added (birth) and removed (death) connections. After about 2500 birth-death events, the posterior probabilities in each GM were computed. The convergence procedure selected the network with the highest posterior probabilities, providing clinicians with the most probable relationships of dysfunctional categories among patients;

Ising model construction – the Ising model was built from pairwise interactions between binary variables, calculating the strength and direction of interactions among functional categories. Positive weights represented the positive interactions, where the presence (or absence) of one functional category increased the likelihood of the presence (or absence) of another. For example, improved self-efficacy in swallowing-related tasks might positively correlate with better overall well-being.36 Negative weights represented the negative interactions, indicating that the presence (or absence) of one functional category decreases the likelihood of the presence (or absence) of another. Interaction strength was represented by the absolute value of weights, with larger values indicating stronger connections. The residue (intercept) for each category in the Ising model represents the inherent value of a node, independent of the influence of other nodes, reflecting the baseline level of a certain function before rehabilitation intervention;

Bayesian posterior probability-corrected Ising network – we cooperated Bayesian network connection probabilities into the Ising network, retaining only connections with posterior probabilities over 0.5, yielding a Bayesian posterior probability-corrected Ising network. Using this adjusted network, we applied perturbation simulations as described by Lunansky et al.23 Residuals of each functional category were reduced by two standard deviations, with simulation sampling performed through the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm, generating 5,000 binary records. This process enabled us to simulate and examine the potential impact of improving certain functions on the entire functional network, helping clinicians predict which dysfunction to improve might have the most beneficial cascading effects across multiple functional domains.

sec.p: Through the above analysis, we calculated the OBI for each category, which quantifies the potential benefit of targeting specific categories for intervention, thereby identifying the optimal treatment targets. Additionally, we analyzed correlations between the OBI resulting from the Ising model and the item difficulty values derived from IRT11 (Supplementary Digital Material 1: Supplementary Table I).

sec.title: Network parameters and visualization
sec.p: A visualization of the maximal spanning tree (MST) was plotted to illustrate the structural characteristics of the main component. The MST connects all nodes in the network without forming cycles, maximizing the total weight of the edges to highlight the strongest pathways.

To quantitatively describe the features of individual nodes, several metrics were employed, centering on a specific functional item, referred to as “ego.” These metrics include: 1) degree (DEG) and weighted degree (wDEG) – DEG measures the number of connections a given ego node has, whereas wDEG accounts for the cumulative strength or weight value of those connections. A higher wDEG signifies that the ego exerts a more pronounced influence within the network; 2) betweenness (BET) – BET quantifies the extent to which a node lies on the shortest paths between other nodes, ranging from 0 to 1. Higher BET values indicate that the ego serves as a critical bottleneck, meaning other nodes rely on it to participate in the whole structure; 3) Hub Score (HUB) – HUB reflects the centrality of the ego as an information center, based on the quantity and strength of its connections and those of adjacent nodes. HUB is normalized from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating a more pivotal network position; 4) coreness (COR) – COR assesses the centrality of a node based on the k-core decomposition. Nodes with low degrees are iteratively removed until only those with degrees greater than k (an integer ≥1) remain (a higher COR value signifies a more central network position); and 5) Laplacian centrality (LAP) – LAP assesses the impact of removing the ego on overall network connectivity.37 A higher LAP value indicates that the ego is more indispensable to network integrity.
Finally, we calculated Pearson correlations to examine the relationships between these network parameters and both the adjusted difficulty11 and OBI of dysphagia-related symptoms.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: One hundred fifty individuals with non-esophageal dysphagia, including 105 males and 45 females, were enrolled in this study. The participants had an average age of 65.95 years, with 70% being male. The median of Body Mass Index (BMI) was 23.74, with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of (15.90; 29.77). In accordance with the principle of maximum heterogeneity sampling,38 the demographic characteristics, are detailed in our previously published manuscript.11

Regarding the distribution of dysphagia types in our sample, one patient had preoral dysphagia, two patients had preoral and oral dysphagia, one patient had oral dysphagia, 109 patients had preoral and oropharyngeal dysphagia, 25 patients had oropharyngeal dysphagia, and 12 patients had pharyngeal dysphagia. Among the participants, 127 individuals (84.67%) had a gastrostomy tube, and 58 patients (38.67%) had undergone tracheotomy.

The median SWAL-QoL questionnaire score was 118.50 (95% CI: 94.18-162.55), while the median score of MMSE was 27.00 (95% CI: 15.45-30.00). The median MNA-SF score was 9 (95% CI: 4.72-11.28), and the median number of swallows on the RSST was 2.00 (95% CI: 0.00-5.00). For the MWST, 5 (3.33%) were at level I, 13 (8.67%) at level II, 89 (59.33%) at level III, 42 (28.00%) at level IV, and 1 (0.67%) at level V. On the FOIS, 87 (58.00%) were at level 1, 10 (6.67%) at level 2, 11 (7.33%) at level 3, 17 (11.33%) at level 4, 24 (16.00%) at level 5, and 1 (0.67%) at level 5.

sec.title: Graph modeling
sec.p: The Ising network was constructed with 50 nodes and 64 connections. The OBI analysis was based on the posterior probabilities derived from the Bayesian structure learning model. Figure 2 further visualizes the impact of the simulation for intervention.

caption.p: —Distribution of the OBI of a specific functional intervention as derived from the Ising model. The error bars (yellow vertical dashed line) represent 84% CI. Items to the left of the vertical dashed line within the 84% CI are associated with significant OBI of a specific functional intervention. Items to the right of the 84% CI dashed line have non-significant OBI. OBI: Overall Benefit Index; CI: confidence interval.

sec.p: The CI for the total functional performance score with intervention does not overlap with the CI for the score without intervention. This non-overlapping of CIs signifies a substantial reduction in the total dysfunction score, indicating a significant therapeutic benefit. Based on the significant level of 0.05, we adopted a more narrow 84% CI rather than the conventional 95% or 90% CI for precise statistical significance.39, 40 As shown in Supplementary Digital Material 2 (Supplementary Table II), 48 functional categories demonstrated significant OBI based on the simulation of dysfunction alleviating, which can influence the overall functional performance. The top three categories with the highest OBI were “d9102 Ceremonies” (OBI=1.00), “d9204 Hobbies” (OBI=0.862), and “d9205 Socializing” (OBI=0.847).

As shown in Figure 3, the Monte Carlo-adjusted item difficulty is strongly correlated with the degree of the OBI (P<0.001, rPearson = 0.712), indicating that the ease of improving a dysfunctional task is inversely related to the OBI. Specifically, dysfunctional tasks that are easy to improve might not contribute significantly to the overall improvement in function.

caption.p: —The correlation between the Monte Carlo-adjusted item difficulty and the Overall Benefit Index of a specific functional intervention. The X axis is Monte Carlo adjusted difficulty; the Y axis is the Treatment Benefit Index. OBI: Overall Benefit Index of specific functional intervention.

sec.title: Visualization of the maximal spanning tree of the main component
sec.p: As shown in Figure 4, the MST of the main component included 36 out of the 50 nodes, displaying a core-periphery structure. MST captures the most likely risk-related pathways by selecting the path with the largest sum of edge weights among all possible connected paths. Notably, “e250 Sound” showed significant associations with both “b110 Attention functions” and “b51058 Swallowing, other specified,” as well as “e260 Air quality.”

caption.p: —Item difficulty-dependent graphical modeling and personal competence from item response modeling for patient H., D.-D. Functional items that are impaired are indicated in orange, whereas those that are normally functioning are highlighted in green. Items with round icons represent functions falling below the personal competence as estimated by IRM, whereas items with square icons denote certain functions exceeding the IRM-estimated personal competence. IRM: Item Response Modeling.

sec.p: “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” emerged as highly central, with the highest Hub Score and Laplacian centrality, as well as the 3rd highest weighted degree. This node was not only associated with “e250 Sound” but also interconnected with “d560 Drinking,” “b51051 Pharyngeal swallowing,” “b620 Urination functions,” and “b730 Muscle power functions.”

Supplementary Table II lists seven key parameters that describe the location and importance of each item within the MST. The highest OBI dysfunctional tasks “d9102 Ceremonies” did not occupy a central or hub location. In terms of Hub Score, “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” (1.000), “b7508 Motor Reflex Functions, other Specified” (0.384), and “b455 Exercise Tolerance Functions” (0.340) were the top three functional items, indicating their centrality and influence.

The top-ranking items for Laplacian centrality were “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” (58), “b730 Muscle Power Functions” (44), and “d9102 Ceremonies” (32), highlighting their importance to the network structure. Additionally, after “d9102 Ceremonies” (6.913), the items “e225 Climate” (4.653) and “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” (4.549) had the highest weighted degrees.

The difficulty level of dysfunctional tasks calculated through IRM, correlated significantly with the network parameters (Figure 5), including DEG (P=0.019, rPearson=0.330), HUB (P=0.008, rPearson=0.373), and LAP (P=0.023, rPearson=0.321).

caption.p: —Heatmap correlation between network parameters and adjusted item difficulty, as well as the overall benefit of a specific functional intervention.

sec.p: The OBI also showed strong correlations with DEG (P<0.001, rPearson=0.519), wDEG (P<0.001, rPearson=0.667), BET (P=0.027, rPearson=0.313), HUB (P=0.001, rPearson=0.449), and the LAP (P<0.001, rPearson=0.500). These findings suggest that both task difficulty and overall benefit are closely related to network centrality measures (Table I).

table-wrap-foot.p: CI: confidence intervals; adj_difficulty: Monte Carlo-adjusted item difficulty; DEG: degree; wDEG: weighted degree; BET: Betweenness; HUB: Hub Score; LAP: Laplacian centrality; OBI: Overall Benefit Index of a specific functional intervention.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study employed graph modeling techniques to investigate the relationships among dysphagia-related ICF functional items. The MST visualizes the positions and the relationships among dysphagia-related ICF functional items, factoring in the difficulty level of each item as derived from IRT. Additionally, the Ising model combined with Bayesian learning estimated the OBI, quantitatively measuring how improvements in individual dysphagia-related dysfunction could influence overall functional outcomes.

Integrating IRT with GMs could strengthen the graphical representation of symptoms by combining IRT’s precision measurement of individual symptom difficulty levels with GM’s analysis of interrelated symptoms. The network approach highlights symptom-to-symptom interactions,41 offering a quantitative view of each symptom’s influence or “weight” within the overall dysphagia framework. Clinicians can rank symptoms by their difficulty and influence, thereby establishing focused rehabilitation goals. Visualizing this hierarchy provides clear guidance for prioritizing treatment pathways, helping clinicians target symptoms with the greatest potential to enhance functional outcomes.

sec.title: Person ability-matched and Overall Benefit Index-guided goal setting
sec.p: The IRT-derived item-person map or the Wright map serves as a valuable tool for person ability-matched goal setting.11 By examining the distribution of θ values alongside item difficulties in Figure 6, healthcare providers can assess the difficulty level of functional tasks relative to the capabilities of the individuals being evaluated.

caption.p: —Examination of the distribution of θ values alongside item difficulties.

sec.p: For patient H., D.-D.’s, “d9102 Ceremonies” is identified as the most challenging functional item, with a difficulty parameter of 2.215 logits, which exceeds H., D.-D.’s functional performance of 0.6944 logits. In contrast, “e250 Sound,” with a difficulty parameter of -0.149 logits, falls within H., D.-D.’s person ability competency area but still exhibits dysfunction. Additionally, “b140 Attention functions” and “b545 Water, mineral and electrolyte balance functions,” both with a difficulty parameter of 0.7427 logits, are slightly higher than H., D.-D.’s functional performance (0.6944 logits). Comparing the difficulty levels of improving these dysfunctions, improving “d9102 Ceremonies” may require greater therapeutic effort (higher difficulty) compared to “e250 Sound” for this patient with moderate ability. However, the Ising model has calculated “d9102 Ceremonies” to have the highest OBI. Despite its challenges, targeting this item could significantly improve the overall functional performance for patient H., D.-D.

During discussions of rehabilitation goals between patients and healthcare providers, healthcare providers can offer experts’ insights into the difficulty and the OBI of improving each dysfunction. For example, if H., D.-D. sets a goal to attend ceremonies, the healthcare provider could inform the patient about the person ability level, as well as the difficulty parameter and OBI of “d9102 Ceremonies” (difficulty parameter = 2.215, OBI=1) and “e250 Sound” (difficulty parameter = -0.149, OBI=0.2191). If H., D.-D. remains committed to attending ceremonies as a goal, healthcare providers will honor the patient’s decision to uphold patient-centered care. The treatment plan should outline each step necessary to achieve this goal.

sec.title: Graphical model-directed goal setting
sec.p: Within the symptom network for dysphagia, certain symptoms play critical roles, acting as “central” or “bridge” symptoms that connect symptom clusters or anchor the network’s structure.42 These pivotal symptoms are essential in treatment planning, as they significantly influence the progression of related symptoms. As shown in Figure 4, “e250 Sound” was identified as an impaired ICF code but the “easiest” item within H., D.-D’s competence. Its central position underscores its importance in dysphagia-related symptoms and its potential as a therapeutic target. “e250 Sound” also had significant associations with “b140 Attention functions” and “b51058 Swallowing, other specified.” Among these impaired categories, “e250 Sound,” with the lowest difficulty, falls within subject H., D.-D.’s competence, suggesting it as a potential entry point for intervention. Researchers have also suggested that minimizing distractions to enhance swallowing safety during meals is crucial, especially for dysphagia patients with cognitive challenges. Studies suggest that a sound-rich environment, as opposed to a silent one, may prolong mealtime. It may indicate a need for environmental modifications to improve safety during feeding activities.43-45
“b51058 Swallowing, other specified” was assessed with the question: “do you frequently cough or need to clear your throat while eating or drinking?”

Research highlights the need to monitor coughing during meals for individuals with compromised swallowing, as it poses significant psychological and social challenges. Interviews with dysphagia patients reveal that coughing episodes during meals create stress and embarrassment, leading to social withdrawal and avoidance of communal dining.46, 47 Moreover, 20-30% of individuals with dysphagia experience silent aspiration,48 which is hard to detect yet heightens the risk of chronic lung diseases.49 In the GM, the ICF category “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” was the central hub in the network, marked by the greatest betweenness, Laplacian centrality, Hub Score, and one of the highest weighted degrees. Although “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” held the most critical position within the MST, the Figure 6 showed “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” featured within the challenging area regarding the H., D.-D’s person ability.11 Considering “b51058 Swallowing, other specified” is also significantly associated with “e250 Sound,” improving “e250 Sound” could facilitate the improvement of “b51058 Swallowing, other specified.”

“d9102 Ceremonies” displayed the highest weighted degree, revealing its significant local influence. It demonstrated significant associations with several ICF categories, including “d9205 Socializing,” “d9204 Hobbies,” “d9300 Organized Region,” and “d9100 Informal Associations.” Despite its challenges, targeting this item could enhance social and community engagement and yield overall functional improvements.

Network indicators, such as degree, Hub Score, and Laplacian centrality, correlated strongly with adjusted item difficulty and OBI, indicating these indicators can help assess the difficulty of enhancing specific functional items and OBI directly. Additionally, our findings revealed a positive correlation between the Monte Carlo-adjusted item difficulty and the OBI for certain functional items. This suggested that the ease of improving a specific function was inversely related to its impact on overall functional performance. In other words, functional categories that are easier to improve tend to have a lower impact on overall functional performance. For instance, dysphagia-related ICF items like “b144 Memory function” that is easier to address may not significantly boost overall improvement of patients’ performance. Therefore, rehabilitation strategies should balance ease of improvement with potential impact to maximize outcomes.

Guided by parametric IRM and GM, this approach encourages shared decision-making, allowing patients to choose between simpler, lower-impact treatments and more challenging, high-impact options, rather than leaving these choices solely to healthcare providers.

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: This pilot study offers a foundation for future research, but some limitations require attention and refinement in subsequent studies. First, the study sample included was limited to 150 individuals with non-esophageal dysphagia. While this sample size met the criteria for graph modeling based on Bayesian structure learning to detect the real network structure,50 with the ratio of the number of observations to the number of items (N./P ratio = 3, N.=150 persons, P=50 items), more robust results are required larger sample size. Future studies with larger, multi-center samples would allow for a more comprehensive exploration of ICF codes, involving a representation of participants with different stages of dysphagia and those affected by specific disease types, thereby improving the generalizability of findings. Second, the current study was cross-sectional, capturing data at a single time point. While this methodology provided an opportunity to reveal dysphagia-related functional networks, it did not reflect the progression of functional changes over time. Incorporating longitudinal data in future studies could clarify the dynamic nature of dysphagia-related syndromes. Additionally, it would be valuable to investigate the more aspiration-related indicators in future iterations of the model. Third, we utilized the Ising model to focus on the presence of symptoms (binary indicators) rather than symptoms severity (continuous indicators). Further study could incorporate alternative models that account for symptom severity as a covariate within the network framework. Finally, our findings were derived from simulation analyses, which necessitate empirical validation. Direct measurement and experimental interventions are essential for confirming the OBI. Developing targeted interventions across dysphagia symptoms and rigorously assessing their tangible benefits would provide practical validation of our theoretical models, thereby strengthening the evidence base in dysphagia research.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study introduces a more comprehensive, data-driven approach to dysphagia rehabilitation. The GM offers a promising approach to visualize the complex associative structure of the dysphagia symptom network. By integrating difficulty levels from the item response model and the OBI from the Ising model, this framework offers a quantitative basis for engaging patients in decisions about treatment priorities.

caption.p: Network parameters of ICF items in the MST.
